keyTakeAways: Smartmatic, a voting technology company, is facing foreign bribery charges from the U.S. Justice Department related to alleged payments in the Philippines to secure election contracts in 2016.
The charges do not allege voter fraud or election rigging in U.S. elections, but are instead tied to international business dealings.

The indictment may significantly weaken Smartmatic’s claims in ongoing defamation lawsuits against Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, Rudy Giuliani, and Mike Lindell, who have accused the company of vote fraud in the 2020 election.
Smartmatic has denied wrongdoing, claiming the indictment is politically motivated and that it has cooperated fully with federal authorities.
The Philippine scandal, first reported by CNN in 2023, has been used by pro-Trump figures to undermine Smartmatic's reputation and damage its claims of defamation-related losses.

Legal experts argue that the indictment complicates Smartmatic’s ability to prove that its reputation damage stems solely from defamatory statements, potentially invalidating or weakening its damages claims in court.

Smartmatic’s voting systems are used overseas but only in Los Angeles County, U.S., where the county asserts it owns and controls its systems and has valid contracts with Smartmatic that include protections against price inflation or add-on fees.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Smartmatic, a global voting technology company, is facing foreign bribery charges from the U.S. Department of Justice over alleged $1 million payments to a top Philippine election official in 2016 to secure election contracts. The charges do not allege voter fraud in U.S. elections, and Smartmatic denies wrongdoing, claiming the case is politically motivated. The indictment could severely undermine Smartmatic’s standing in ongoing defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures including Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, Rudy Giuliani, and Mike Lindell, who have long accused the company of rigging the 2020 election. These figures have used the bribery allegations to argue that Smartmatic’s reputation is damaged by both defamatory claims and criminal conduct, complicating Smartmatic’s ability to prove that its damages stem solely from false statements. Los Angeles County asserts it owns and controls its own voting systems and that its contracts with Smartmatic are valid and protected. Legal experts note the indictment may weaken Smartmatic’s damages claims and impact settlement negotiations. The case, first revealed by CNN in 2023, represents a major development in the broader political and legal conflict over election integrity and the credibility of voting technology companies.
title: Smartmatic Indicted in Foreign Bribery Case, Possibly Endangering Its Lawsuits Against Fox News and Giuliani
